name: INK
description: INK is a fast-paced platformer about using colorful paint to uncover your surroundings. Defeat all enemies in the room and reach the goal! However, the terrain is invisible, so you need to discover the terrain by physically bumping into it, by performing a double jump or by, well, dying.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or Later Processor: 2 GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: 512 MB VRAM DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 30 MB available space Sound Card: Yes Additional Notes: The game runs at locked 30 FPS.
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or Later Processor: 3 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 1 GB VRAM DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 60 MB available space Sound Card: Yes Additional Notes: The game runs at locked 30 FPS.

reviews.review_text: A masterpiece, an absalute treat to play with very little to complain about!  Good: - A unique mechanic/gimic that is very VERY well implimented, makes a very personal feeling world with very pretty colours and therefore making dark confusing world into a bight vivid one. - A well designed death system, I'm not quite sure what to call this but the way the developers made it so that dyingis not always bad, it works so that dying now just a way to discover more bits of the level, that is until you splat the entire level with ink, then dying has no benefits, as it should be. The way that only double jumps splat ink everywhere is a great choice making levels more difficult and interesting. - A good difficulty curve, as a good precision platformerer like myself you would not find anything in the first 2 world too difficult and the 3rd world will get challenging, for newer players the game eases in to the difficulty very well making sure that the first 15-20 levels won't be tough, neither will the first boss. The game DOES get difficult and you will die many MANY times in your playthrough(s). Each enemy is brought in at a good time so levels don't feel repetative and then once you know hoe they behave, they get diffucult again. - Enemies are very predictable and the fact that they leave ink trails just adds to pretty nature of the game. I do have a few issues with the basic enemies as seen below - The physics is very nice and floaty simular to Super Meat Boy, it feels a bit slippery as you'd expect and suits the game well. - Fantastic level design, some levels are repeated with extra difficulty and enemies and I can't fault any level! - It is a great speedrun for people who want to get into speedrunning or for experienced runners, it becomes a test of memory to complete it, very fun!   Mixed: - Bosses are well done although I do have a few problems, the 2nd boss took me a while to figure out what I needed to do, once I'd done that it wasn't too bad and also the final boss (quite rightfully) alot harder than the others making it an interesting fight, it is hard but once you know the attacks it becomes quite easy to manipulate to your advantage, otherwise the bosses are well made, the first one is a great introduction to how you damage them. All in all well designed! - When you kill enemies, your sometimes feel like you can't get away from triggers that crush you, this maybe because you didn't hold the other direction soon enough. - For experienced precision plateformerers, the game can feel a little bit short but with mensions of DLC with more levels AND potential steam workshop support (one of the developers said this may be a possability when I talked to them) it should get even more reasons to play.  Bad: - Ememies. I have 2 problems with the normal enemies in this game:  1) The fact that you don't get your double jumo back after killing them (this is just personal preferance and is probably a design choice),  2) Going into the side of enemies feels inconsistant whether or not they die, again there may or may not be something I do not understand about this.   Conclusion: Very well made, solid game with minimal faults, definatly worth playing! I are a few issues but PLEASE don't let that put you off because this game is truely fabulous. It's so different and so interesting that anyone that gets this far through reading this review NEEDS TO PLAY THIS GAME...   NOW!!!

There's not much to say about this game so I will give a list of pros/cons and then give some thoughts on it.  PROS +Unique concept that works well +Looks really nice (sort of... more on this later*) +Fast-paced gameplay with usually pretty good level design +Nice amount of options for default controls; anything most people would want to use can be used  CONS -Capped at 30 frames per second... terrible -*Game is rendered at a low resolution -Inconsistent controls; especially in the air -Hitting corners at a certain angle will kill you for seemingly no reason -Homing projectiles home in way too accurately and are too difficult to dodge -Music is lackluster -Game is very short; 1.5 hours and I'm done already -No options menu: this means... -Resolution can not be changed, nor can the game be put into a windowed mode; it is fullscreen by default -Anything else that usually comes with an options menu cannot be changed  To expand on some of the points;  The inconsistent controls are one of this game's biggest problems; the momentum is very inconsistent. Trying to adjust the momentum of a jump whilst mid-air feels more like luck than anything else; you may completely change direction or you may just slow down. It's unnacceptable.  The homing projectiles can spin a full circle (360 degrees!) if you dodge them and will continue to home in on you, Need I say more?  I like the concept; it's really unique and works well. It pains me to write a negative review on this game. Unfortunately, the game is poorly built and very short. With all the issues this game has, I can't reccomend it. Even if the developers fixed all of the issues I've listed, I still would not reccomend that you buy this game at full price. Seeing as how the game only lasted me 1.5 hours, I'd pay 4 bucks for it at the very most.  If one of the developers reads what follows this, they will surely be insulted, but it's the truth, and it's the best way to sum up the review:  There are better, free flash games out there. Don't waste your money.

This game is a slight breath of fresh air if you've had a hard time finding a new platformer worth playing lately. Making the player become the catalyst that reveals the platforms that are hidden adds a surprisingly non-obtrusive mechanic to the platforming in INK. The very bright contrasting colors your character (Of seemingly white light or something of the sort) shoots out colors across the spectrum when it double jumps, runs along the ground, or meets its early demise.  Dying almost becomes an additional tool to aid you in completeing a level, and for obvious purpose. The soundtrack is very ambient and calming, which complements the early levels of INK, but make no mistake, the difficulty does ramp up in time!  Controls feel tight and reminiscient of Super Meat Boy, I don't feel cheated if I fall to my death because its not typically because of a bugged jump or something of the sort.   All pros aside, there is one con I find that detracts enough that it is worth mentioning. This game seems to be capped at 30 FPS and it shows when the colored ink flies through the air, or when you move your character around. The bright and very contrasting colors can also be a factor if your prone to eye strain from numerous bright/saturated colors.  I would say this game is definitely worth playing, but I truly hope the Devs make it so it runs at 60 FPS, and you can swap out the color pallete of the ink with different palletes, like monochromatic, split complementary, and other color schemes, rather than just super bright colors.  8/10, I will be playing this more and more.
Super Meat Boy Jackson Pollock Edition

Well well, now here's a surprisingly simple yet fun and hard game. Platformers aren't really my thing, but this game is a welcomed exception.  I usually don't do reviews but this game does deserve one. This is probably one of the more challenging platformers I've ever had the pleasure of playing. And I love a good challenging game. Makes me think over just what it is that I have to do in order to advance to the next part of the level; how can I make this jump; how is this jump even possible; how do I even get that coin?! This game forces you to think fast, something I'm not used to, but something I definitely appreciate. The fast pace of the game only adds to the challenge, because you have to tap your keys just enough to make that landing or risk overshooting it. Oh man, and the complexity of the jumps you have to make is just well thought out. Kudos to the developer for putting complexity into simplicity. The only thing that I am kind of frustrated with is...my tendency to hit the 'A' button when really I want to hit the 'D' button. Damn me and my weak hand-eye coordination.  But overall, I give this game a 9/10. Why? Because sometimes a simple game can be just as good as a game like Skyrim. Definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for fun and a simple challenge in their gameplay.
This is basically super meat boy, but for kids. It's still a fun, hard, and a keyboard breaking game.

INK is a fun little platforming challenge in the weeeee bit too close vein of Super Meat Boy that is quite short and I cautiously recommend.  I'm not particularily good at platforming, but not entirely bad either. With that in mind; I beat the game in one sitting in 94mins (my playtime may go up to farm cards). With 75 levels the game is broken into thirds with a boss marking each 25th level. The real challenge isn't found until the final third of the game. It takes the Super Meat Boy endless life approach with short levels, slidy controls, wall jumping, double jumping and blood stains left over from the last life. There is even a similar behaving key system and similar 'smart' projectiles in that challenging final third of INK. The one unique thing it has going is that every level starts blind. And your 'blood' is colorful ink that paints your surroundings and reveals the task at hand. Deaths as well as double jumping spews the colorful ink about. Its interesting in its own right but I wish the rest of the game was as original.   While I had fun and enjoyed the challenge my recommendation is very reserved. Its too short and way too familiar to pay full price for even if that price is low. This is a perfect bundle game though.

Looks amazing, great idea that I liked very much. also really fun, but controlls are inconsistent and completly off.  The jump hight seems to be completly random, I can barely navigate the ink blob across the platform. What happens when I jump next to a wall? will I stick to it and combo jump? will I jump to the other direction? will I fall? no one knows, a mystery! Really wanted to enjoy this game, hope the devs get a patch out that sorts the controlls issue.

Oh, for gods sake, there is no 100% control of the character. The movement on air continues even if I stop pressing forward. Also the character performs a wall jump even if I am not pressing agains the wall.. just because it is next to a wall...  Please fix this

This is a fun little game if you like somewhat challenging platformers. The final third of the game gets pretty difficult at times, but that just makes it that much sweeter when you beat it. Absolutely worth $4.99.

This is a fun little game if you like somewhat challenging platformers. The final third of the game gets pretty difficult at times, but that just makes it that much sweeter when you beat it. Absolutely worth $4.99.
A Beautiful little indie platformer with some awesome ideas that add some great things to the genre!
0.4 hours in and my thumb already hurts from pressing A.   10/10 would get repetative strain injury again.

Not only did gaming in 2015 consist of some amazing platformers, 2015 was also the year game’s decided to throw some paint around! INK is a twitch-platformer based on the principle of learning from your mistakes. Anything the player touches leaves spatters of paint on its surface. Even when the player dies, paint is released. This basic mechanic instills a sense of discovery in a subgenre that often misses the mark in this regard. INK is definitely one of those ‘just one more level’ type of games, and maybe one of the most addictive games of 2015. What seems so simple on the surface turns out to be one of 2015’s best games. If you loved twitch-platformers or want to get into the genre but don’t know where to start, INK is a game I can’t recommend enough.

Take this with a grain of salt; platformers aren't exactly my favortite genre.  While the invisble until you color it in thing for the levels is novel, this plays like your typical platformer except for being permenantly stuck in 'the ice level'. I dunno about you, but I have always hated the ice level in every platformer game to have one. I do not enjoy sliding out of control.  You defeat enemies by jumping onto them super mario style. I couldn't play this on a keyboard, had to map it to my controller with joytokey. There doesn't seem to be any way to remap the controls in game at all.  If you are the sort that loves 'the ice level' of <mario game here> you will likely enjoy this game. Theres no middle ground between steams 'yes' and 'no' here and I'm obviously not into it, so I'm giving this a no..
bad hitboxes, repetitive level design,annoying enemies

This game was made by a very good programmer who managed to do a nice looking game with probably poor art skills.  - Tight gameplay - Simple art - Short game - Music is only ok - Bosses could have been harder  I would recommend the game to platformer lovers and speedrunners.  7/10
8/10, would play splatoon meatboy again. That would be, if I could get past *that level..*

nteresting game, not totally bad, not totally good. It could be way better with improved controls. The controls are innatural, inaccurate. The game itself tends to get boring and repetitive very soon, but you can go back to it from time to time in order to solve a couple of levels. It definitely needs an overhaul to the controls system though.

This is a platformer that takes an innovative concept and makes something beautiful out of it. It's short and challenging, but very fun. It takes Super Meat Boy's challenge and combines it with the goal of splattering paint everywhere in order to see the area, playing with the concept of the unknown environment around you. The game starts out with exploration as the focus, making you use your paint to discover the level around you, and ends with ridiculous challenge as you die hundreds of times trying to dodge projectiles among showers of color. There are collectibles that are very difficult to find unless you splatter paint everywhere, and most require you to think outside the box to reach.  Overall, the game is short but well worth the money. I've never seen this concept before, and especially wouldn't have expected to see it done so well without another game like it out there. It's about 2 hours long if you're experienced with platformers, but it was more worthy of my money than a 2 hour long movie would have been, and it costs much less than a ticket would have.

tl;dr - Good concept executed poorly  Pros: + Unique concept with main gimmick fleshed out well + No tutorials (not necessary) + Good progression of design  Cons: - Sloppy controls - Too much replaying necessary to complete a level - Difficulty is all over the place  The basis of the game is it's a puzzle platformer with a strong action portion. You must get to the end of the level, and more requirements are necessary to get there as the levels progress from defeating enemies and unlocking areas. More mechanics are gradually introduced, often shocking you at first but nearly immediately becoming easy to understand so no tutorials are necessary. The mechanic of revealing the platforms around you is done as well as I'd like it to be done, and as the main gimmick I feel it was a strong point, however....  After the first boss the difficulty increases dramatically. This however is a nice change from the fairly easy preceeding levels. After the second boss, the difficulty changes for the worse, making most levels just a matter of memorizing the exact second to jump, trying to ignore the constant screen shaking from enemies and ink splattering, and trying your hardest to do everything frame perfect. Combined with the inertia and sloppy controls, it makes it more frustrating than fun. Combined with heat seeking missles that are faster than you, it becomes a real chore. The final boss was a good design, however how to damage it seemed inconsistent - what would hurt it one time kills you another with no discernable reason as to why. There is some replay value as there's a hidden item in (seemingly) each level, however I would not be inclined to play through again to collect them.
Pretty fun Super Meat Boy clone, but I cleared all the levels in less than 2 hours.  It's worth buying, but probably try to get it during a sale.

Well, it copies the Super Meatboy movement mechanics pretty closely, so I guess if you're starved for more Super Meatboy levels and are not offended by invisible spike traps and leaps of faith to your death that tend to make you die a few extra times beyond what the level's difficulty deserves, then this game is fine for you.

Controls are unresponsive. 30fps lock just makes it that much worse. Maybe I'm just spoiled by how tight Meat Boy is, but this just feels clunky and unresponsive.  Concept seems fun but the bad controls just hurt the experience too much. I got this in a Humble Bundle, so it's not a big deal, but I would not recommend anyone buy this outright.

When I first got the game not long after it was released, I quickly cleared the entire game, and got a few of the achievements before putting it down and forgetting about it. A year later I've picked it up again and can't put it down. Not only is the game beautiful visually, but it's one of those rare platformers that I feel the controls are responsive and solid feeling. I rather enjoy trying to perfect my times in the game, and working towards the no-death achievements has been very challenging but very fun.
boring 18 minutes into it couldnt do it take it anymore
It starts out as a cute, colorful little platformer.  Then it almost literally turns into Super Meat Boy.  With the lights out.  Not nearly as hard or frustrating though, which is nice.

First things first: This game is fun to play. Thanks to the coorperation of 'Team Meat', who developed 'Super Meat Boy' long time ago, this title acts similar in its gameplay. You have a block colored in white ink and your aim is to explore the map of each level and find the exit to the next level with a total number of 75 levels. After every boss the following stages prove your skills as it gets harder and harder while you progress. On top of that you get a wonderful colored scenery by yourself just by playing and a great balanced background music, which never lets you down.  pro:  + colorful gameplay + supports gamepad (same as in SMB  'Thumbs before Fingers' ; you better use one) + challenging levels (when you want to get the achievements, even the first levels can break your neck) + great background music  con:  - although it has 75 levels, you are pretty quickly done with each of it - screenshots cannot be taken,  YET  (neither with F12 or any other shortcuts you apply to it)   P.S.: For all the SMB player out there: This game is a bit easier to handle and more colorful than SMB ever was.  Give that game a try and have fun playing :)
this game is hard... (understatement of the year)

I really tried to enjoy INK, but it has a simple, yet fundamental problem: the controls wall-jumping on most platforms, especially ones that require extreme percision, is needlessly difficult. the sliding is like Luigi in Melee. Except it isn't an endearing character, it's rage-inducing. Having to constantly restart a level because of the sliding physics are actual crap.  While a very pretty game with a cool concept, it becomes needlessly tedious and the awe of ingenuity quickly wanes. Unfortunately, I can't really recommend this game.
Boring and repetitive
FIrst step buy the game second step paint ink everything with colours :o

It has an awesome system where you have to find the stage as you play the game, you need to make your way over to certain objectives in order to unlock the exit and somtimes the exit is simply open and available and the task is to simply find your way there. There is one problem however that makes it diffficult to complete this simple and awesome concept, in order to add a difficulty, once you have painted the entire stage, they added a momentum based movement. seeing that there are small platforms to land on, preforming a wall jump and then landing on said platform it is common to go flying off of it. This momentum will also continue if you land on an enemy, if you land on an enemy that is close to the edge of the stage you will be forced to continue your momentum to your death. Though it has an awesome concept, dying, due to flying farther than you want, is a bit too common. I cannot say if the evel design helps this mechanic once reaching farther levels due to not wanting to play a frustrating game.

What are the thumbs-up people smoking?!? Can I please have some of THAT instead of this game?  Here's the game in a nutshell: A bad platformer you wouldn't play for free, where they've hidden all the platforms and you don't get to see them until you die dozens of times each level. Oh, and there's technicolor vomit everywhere.  Player skill doesn't enter the picture, it's a matter of whether you're bull-headed enough to plow through this bag of festering bovine stool.
A very relaxing game and the platforming mechanics are amazing

This game have a very big potencial and that game have + and -: +Very good gameplay +Audio is OK +Interesing mechanics -only some controllers work -insufficient levels My rating is 8/10 I think that helped a Reply you :)
0love the art style of this game ut somwtimes it says that i have double jumped when i have only jumped onece. But overall a very ice looking and fun game
very hard but very fun
super meat boy but less hard, and the level is invisible
I Love This game Its So Fun But Sometimes feel like I WANT THIS GAME TO BURN IN HELL WITH SATAN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
INK is a hardcore 2D platformer in the vein of Super Meat Boy. If you like these kind of torture platformers then you should enjoy INK, but if not you will likely become easily frustrated.
Colorful Platformer with good gameplay also good soundtrack.

INK is a fun little platformer which makes excellent use of its initially invisible platforms to make fundamentally simple level designs challenging and fun to explore. However this gimic is largely abandoned with an increasing number of hazards requiring picture perfect precision in timing and jumping. The game suffers from the 'Sonic the Hedgehog' problem which many platformers suffer from; the game feels like it should be smooth and fast, but ultimately ends up being slow and deliberate. There are better platformers which do a much better job of marrying level design and hazards with game mechanics.
Absolutely worth the 5 bucks!

Was able to beat the game in roughly 3 hours but it was worth every minute.  At first, it leans you into the game and lets you get your bearings but soon you start experiencing the 'obstacles.' You than find yourself dodging all kinds of projectiles and squashing enemys.   I'd recommend using controller for this but your mileage may vary as I felt it helped in certain levels.  For roughly $5, it's well worth it.

Fair earning, this game isn't as hard as something like Super Meat Boy. This is a cute diversion with an interesting concept, and, ignoring the no death runs, shouldn't be too difficult for those of you who have cut your teeth on other, harder platformers.  But is it fun? Yes, the concept and style work well together and the game holds really well. I'm surprised to see the number of reviews complain about controls, I found it adequately responsive. It lacks story and characters, but honestly, all of these sorts of games do, just to varying degrees.   Definitely give it a try if you're into 2d indie platformers.

a good game overall. An adjustment I would make would be to be able to gain an extra jump when bouncing off a rectangle enemy. love the art style, very responsive controls and works great with a 360 controller.  100% worth the 29p I got it for on G_2A...

At first I was really into INK. I got it as a part of a bundle and was curious. 5 minutes in I was thinking about the neat visual style and ambient music and how death is actually helpful in a way as it covers new hidden platforms. In fact, even running around covering platforms with ink was fun and I felt a bit of a Splatoon-ish satisfaction for covering as many surfaces as I could. You sort of swapped between scouting out platforms in a level and moving towards the level’s exit. Dying meant little other than a bit more ink near that platform you’ve been struggling on, making it a bit more visible. Finally, I thought, a nice stress-less, enjoyable platformer.   Oops. It was Super Meat Boy in disguise. I mean, I should’ve guessed. Slippery, momentum-based platforming where moving creates a color to show where you have been and where you have died. I don’t know what I was excepting. I guess I was really just hoping for something a bit more relaxing after finishing some homework, buying the bundle containing and then giving it a play before bed.  There was one level that got me frustrated that was pretty early on. I had to do with having to jump from one side of the more longitudinal map to the other killing enemies to unlock the exit. I won’t get into too much detail but there were two enemies place on the far left/right, very close to the edge. When you touch the edge, you die. When you bounce off an enemy, you keep your momentum. So I tried and tried to make a huge jump up to the next platform and then jump on the enemy while also moving a little to the left to avoid hitting the edge but not too far to avoid falling or having the enemy run into me. And it gets weirder because the next level was a breeze. For some reason the game just really wanted me to experience this learning curve and really drive how a kind of minor scenario that could’ve been show through a much less frustrating experience. Heck, in the next handful of levels you don’t even really get close to the walls of the level.  This game, based off the little I’ve played, does this a lot. It has a just rude level that interrupts the occasional string of neutral or fun stages. Plus it’s hard to ‘hate’ at times as the visuals and music are very, can I say…relaxing? Interesting? Whatever it is, they kept me playing.  Meat Boy is a hard game. And I’m the sort of person who isn’t a fan of difficult games despite their more rewarding pay off for beating a level. Completing a level begins to feel more like a chore than a challenge especially when it comes to a scenario where you see yourself die every 15 seconds only to give another shot at preforming perfectly in the same seemingly endless level where you spend 10 minutes dying on the same part only to move forward a little bit but still have to go through and die to the previous part a few more times. That’s kind of what Meat Boy is for me.   It’s only really when you’ve died plenty of times and the bit of ink that is flung up from your death stops helping you that thinks get frustrating. The ‘exploration phase’ is over and now it’s back to the grind stone to perfect your jumps in order to get past the level.  I probably won’t finish it. I know it’s gonna become even more difficult and, well, if I want more stress I can just do Honor’s Bio homework.  Like Meat Boy and colors? It’s a pretty cheap game, give a buy. It certainly got me thinking even if that wasn’t its intension. Oops.  I’ll be honest though: I kinda just feel like someone played a ton of Meat Boy and found themselves trying to paint all the surfaces of each level for fun. XD  [Wait. Did I just play a game for 20 minutes and then basically right an essay on it that compares it to Super Meat Boy while also analyzing what really seems to be the root of why I didn’t like that game too much either? Dam. Rambling 101]
Ive never played Super Meat Boy, but I'd imagine this is what its like.  Enraging, and fun.

INK is a game about making a mess and learning from failure. It is also a game about getting killed by missles and spikes over and over.  It is a great, quick game that I think is well worth your time and money.
Great concept, great execution. Fenomenal simple game. It's challenging, very rewarding and very fun.

This game has a very interesting concept that doesn't pay off very well. While you do have to reveal the level as you go along, this is only novel for the first coupld of attempts on a level. Each level requires quite a few attempts, which, while possible, are annoyingly difficult.  Otherwise, it is a very cool game.

This game is a lot of fun and fast paced yet can be frustrating (mainly because I suck). It is a platforming game where all the platforms are invisable and only show up when you splat ink over them. Be prepared for plenty of trial and error.  If you would like to see a few levels of the game check out my gameplay video  here
Excellent MeatBoy-like with a colorful twist. Precise controls, good soundtrack, HARD. Buy this.

*This is more of a first impression than a full review, just want to state that ahead of time*  The game is simple, beautiful, and most importantly fun.  The visuals are of course colorful and also simple, which works in the games favor. Simple game, simple visuals, but tons of fun. The music is fantastic, very calming and atmospheric, which certainly helps with keeping your cool while playing.  Gameplay is solid and addicting with good controls and physics, although it is slippery. The game also introduces new obstacles along the way and even has boss fights which are pretty cool, something I did not expect. Another thing to add is that when you fail its not that frustrating, you usually can get back to where you were pretty quickly. Half the time when I die, I help msyelf out by reaveling more of the level.  Despite the good there are some things that hold the game back a bit, one being the lack of an option menu. Its a bit annoying not being able to easily adjust the volume or resolution. There is also a 30FPS cap which is also annoying, but its does not kill the expirience.  Despite that, from what I have played so far I would rate this game an 8/10. Simple, but very much worth the $5 price tag
Ive never played Super Meat Boy, but I'd imagine this is what its like.  Enraging, and fun.

That game is funny fun pros +Great idea +very good looking +fun cons -the jump button is hard to get used to ( if you press it to fast you dont jump far, you have to wait atleast 1 sec to jump higher.)
amazing its like super meat boy and splatoon had a baby it was called ink

This game is a bouncy, floaty platformer that practically a rainbow version of super meat boy that has many unique mechanies and lovely visuals that add on to the fun platforming. My only complaint is the controls are too slipperly and floaty that after jumping it's hard to judge where you're going to land because of your momentum always changing while in mid-air. Overall, this is a great game that I think people should check out.  8/10

INK is a good indie game that I really enjoy! I like how the blocks are invisible and that you have to make your 'ink' go everywhere to make the blocks appear. Since I like keeping things short and sweet, I would recommend this game.

Right off the bat this game is awesome. Cool mechanics, good soundtrack, smooth physics, everything a platformer needs. My only gripe about this game is that it dosn't work with my Logitech f310 gamepad. Other than that, a fantastic game and well worth the 3 bucks.

Very fun and and addicting! I have had a lot of fun with this game, and while having still not beaten it, as I am quite bad (at any game for that matter) I love it and will continue to try and beat it, and, eventually, 100% it.

I like the game for it's colorful artstyle and the ways it's trying to vary up it's levels and keep them interesting. Mechanically it's solid but tries nothing too crazy or new. My biggest complaint is the games overall brevity.  Full Review on YouTube
Pretty fun, art style is great. I love the lack of detail and clutter.

a good game overall. An adjustment I would make would be to be able to gain an extra jump when bouncing off a rectangle enemy. love the art style, very responsive controls and works great with a 360 controller.  100% worth the 29p I got it for on G_2A...
this game is relly fun and i like the blind mechanic

This a a good game due to its simplicity, visual design and simplicity. The bad news is the advertised controller support was not there for me. My Xbox 360 wireless controllers work with other games that advertsie controllers support on my current OS.

INK is a basic platformer game with gorgeous pixalated graphics, very similar to Super Meatboy (in my opinion INK is better). It has 75 levels and three of them are boss fights. At first the platforms are invisible and you have to discover the levels by painting them. The gameplay gives a great feeling, of trying and succeding. The first few levels are really easy and then it gets harder and harder. Rage quits are acceptable especially if you are on a level with homing missiles.  If you like platformer games then it's a must buy.
Nice game.

Difficult, stylish, creative game. If you've watched the trailer, you pretty much know what the gameplay entails; the level design is good but frustrating. Controls are somewhat slippery, but it's completely playable and a lot of fun.
Just saw INK in my library and decided What the hell, might as well see what it is. Very fun and simple game. GOod to pass time or just chill out
I love the game, the music, the art style, it's a really great game. One thing I would like to see though is an option menu for the music and sound volume. Could we make that happen?

This would be very relaxing if if weren't for unresponsive controls and the fact that running into level walls kills you and all enemies reset, which it unfortunately makes very frustrating. I like the colors and music and rest of the gameplay, but I cannot recommend this as it gets too tedious.

An infuriating game where you play as Mr. Clean's magic eraser and try to kill all the things, while also rainbow ♥♥♥♥ing on everything in sight. Also there might be hearts somewhere, I don't survive long enough to even see them. 10/10 would die again
Great fun, wonderful art, play this if you enjoy some nice platforming
A fun game that you can play when you're bored. Do expect do die a few (hundred) times. Easy to play, very hard to master.
1 hour playthrough-time of awesome Super Ink Boy! ...with a nice chilling soundtrack ^-^ Totally worth playing!

This game is absolutley stunning! I am no platforming master and can\'t make it past level around 30, however... It is amazing watching the screen transform from a white block into a rainbow of colors. I got this game in a humble bundle so I can\'t speak for price-to-value ratio but consider I can\'t complete it, I would say leave this to those how want a more challenging platformer.

This game is really nice. It is visually pleasing and runs very well. It is also very challanging but still not to hard. Though my only complaint is that its very linear. Either the level is jump from wall to wall avoiding enemys or spikes, or jumo from wall avoiding projectiles. But overall its a fun game!

INK  INK is a fascinatingly beautiful game, perfectly balanced between looking pretty and being enjoyable on a casual basis. Despite having some extremely challenging levels, INK presents this in a complex painting of pixellated paint splashes from every death or double jump.  Pros:  - Looks so cool, with the beautiful pixel graphics - Balanced gameplay, it is possible to complete every level (although some are really difficult) - Shows off the capabilities of GameMaker  Cons:  - Some super difficult levels  Overall, I recommend this game, especially for the art within it, every level ends up with a funky colour scheme. Perfectly combines a challenging platformer with a unique art style.  ~ burgs.exe

This game is an innovatinve, thoroughly enjoyable (and a *little* rage inducing) platformer. It holds many interesting and unique challenges that work well with the mechanics, and the boss battles are well done.  The one particularly regrettable thing is the 30 fps lock. A game like this would be such an incredibly enhanced experience compared to what it is now if it was at 60 fps.
Good game, is fun and hard at the same time ;u;

I like these 'quirky' 'Indy' platformers but I am not verry good at them. so for me the best part about this game is that the dificulty did not out pace my ablity super fast. Others have said that the controlls are bad but to me it feels like a choice rather than a mistake. Edit: was playing some more today and the controlls really did start to feel inconsistant and unresponsive and not just unforgiving. Also I realised that its not just the slipery surface that is a chalange its the way you buld momentum. you continue to build momentum for quite some time after you reach peak speed or jumpdistance so the difuculty of controlling your landing is going to be dependant largely on how long you held the directional button which dosent feal thematic it feals like a mistake.
Im gonna kill myself 10/10 would rage quit a couple 100 times again good buy much worth
Fun game if you like platforming games! I really enjoyed the puzzles
Does it have 20 levels only? Finished 18 in 23 minutes.  Just a regular platformer where you move as if you´re in an ice level.
give me ateam badge

First of all, if you have played and liked either Thomas is Alone or Super Meat Boy, absolutely play this game. If you haven't let me convince you. This is a simple platformer that takes about 4 hours to complete. The game works well and the soundtrack is actually really great. But, the main draw of the game is the visual style. Every time you start a level, you begin on a blank screen. Then, every time you double jump you throw paint everywhere, revealing the platformers and traps of the level. The game is a lot of fun because of that, but it does have some drawbacks. Sometimes the cube you play as feels overly floaty, but otherwise, this is a semi-difficult platformer that you should play.
